headline.print_headline: An Early Skyscraper Becomes a Hotel With a View
headline.main: An Early Skyscraper Becomes a Hotel With a View

docs.abstract: Development of hotel-condo project in Manhattan's financial district comes as area draws more residents and tourists; nine-story brick-and-terracotta building, which was one of New York's first skyscrapers when completed in late 1800s,will be converted into 287-room hotel with condo tower next door.
docs.lead_paragraph: Development of a hotel-condo project in the financial district comes as the area draws more residents and tourists.

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotel Concern Ousts Chief

docs.abstract: InterContinental Hotels Group ousts chief executive Richard North (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The InterContinental Hotels Group said yesterday that it had ousted its chief executive, Richard North, and would search for an executive with greater marketing experience as it focuses on building brands like Holiday Inn. The company, which is based in Windsor, England, said it was looking for a chief executive who can lead its transformation from a company that owns hotels to one that manages or franchises them. Mr. North, 54, will leave at the end of this month, the chairman, David Webster, said. He has been chief executive since October 2002. Mr. Webster said that he would serve as chief executive while the company seeks a successor.

headline.main: Bomb Kills 11 in Pakistan; 9 Are French

docs.abstract: Blast apparently set by suicide bomber in Karachi kills nine French citizens and two Pakistanis; bomb explodes alongside navy bus parked near Sheraton Hotel, where French people were staying while working on submarine project for Pakistani government (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A blast apparently set off by a suicide bomber killed 9 French citizens and 2 Pakistanis today outside a hotel here, the police and hospital officials said. The bomb exploded about 8 a.m. alongside a navy bus that was parked near the Sheraton Hotel, where the French citizens were staying while working on a submarine project for the Pakistani government.

headline.main: On Avenue C, Renewal and Regret

docs.abstract: Herbert Muschamp Critic's Notebook column on the new Sofitel on West 44th Street in Manhattan, which is designed by Yann Leroy, an architect formerly known for his experimental designs and criticism of city's architectural establishment; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Scottish movie ''Trainspotting,'' about young heroin addicts, hit theaters in 1996, some critics called it an advertisement for drug use. But for the residents of 713 East Ninth Street, just east of Avenue C, the film was an opportunity. The residents, calling themselves Dos Blockos, were a close-knit group of squatters inhabiting an abandoned six-story tenement that had been stripped of wires, pipes, anything neighborhood addicts could convert to quick cash. When a glossy magazine wanted an appropriately derelict backdrop for a ''Trainspotting'' photo shoot, the squatters volunteered their homes -- for a location fee of $500 a day. ''We used that money to put plumbing in the building,'' said Dan, who had lived in the squat at the time, and declined to give his last name.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Betsy Wade is undoubtedly correct that "reservations guaranteed on travelers' credit cards get room assignments early" ("Negotiating a Hotel Room," Practical Traveler, Dec. 10). Yet recently the reverse worked to my advantage. Having sent my reservation to Montreal's Center Sheraton for a professional conference, I promptly received written confirmation. Yet upon my early afternoon arrival, I was asked to wait in the lobby as no room was available. The explanation given was that I had omitted my credit card number.

docs.lead_paragraph: The French-owned Sofitel group of seven hotels is sending its guests on their way with an $8.95 box lunch called the Un-Plane Meal. Although suitable for air travelers looking for an alternative to airplane food, an official said, the meals are available to all guests who call room service an hour before departure. The meals include a fruit and cheese appetizer, ham, shrimp, turkey or cheese on lettuce with a baguette, or a homemade sandwich on French bread with pastry or fresh fruit. Both include utensils and mineral water or soda.

headline.print_headline: How Many Stars for the Wi-Fi?
headline.main: How Many Stars for the Wi-Fi?

docs.abstract: Website Hotelwifitest.com ranks hotels in more than 4,000 cities based on their Internet connection speeds, helping business travelers avoid hotels with unreliable Wi-Fi that could impede their ability to access vital data for an important business meeting.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hotels are responding to customer demand with improved Internet connectivity, sometimes offering it free.

headline.seo: Hotel Product Offerings Beyond the Bathrobe

docs.abstract: Some hotel chains have started selling branded products in an effort to lure customers back for another visit; Westin Hotels has been particularly successful with its line of Heavenly branded products, including robes, bedding, lotions and shampoos.
